items.title: Unexpected keyword argument 'seleniumwire_options' in constructor call
items.body:
Hi everyone , thank a lot for read this issue.

I recently use selenium wire for set some http proxy (i use selenium wire in the past and it work perfectly),
but this time an incomprehensible error just broke my plans , 

i nammed it "Unexpected keyword argument 'seleniumwire_options' in constructor call"




my code :
```python
import os
from seleniumwire import webdriver
from selenium.common.exceptions import TimeoutException
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.common.keys import Keys
from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC
from selenium.webdriver.support.wait import WebDriverWait
from seleniumwire.webdriver import Chrome, ChromeOptions
import asyncio
from anonn import getproxies
from anonn import user_agents_switch
#all import



def Bot(url):
        while True:
            try:
                print("Lancement...")
                prox = getproxies()
                seleniumwire_options = {'proxy': prox, 
                                        'connection_timeout': None,
                                        'verify_ssl': False}
                user_agent = user_agents_switch()

                options = ChromeOptions()               #creating Chromeoption()
                options.add_argument('--no-sandbox')
                options.add_argument('--mute-audio')
                options.add_argument('--disable-gpu')
                options.add_argument('--disable-dev-shm-usage')
                options.add_argument(f'--user-agent={user_agent}')

                driver = webdriver.Chrome(options=options,seleniumwire_options=seleniumwire_options,executable_path=r"path") #creating the driver but "Unexpected keyword argument 'seleniumwire_options' in constructor callpylint(unexpected-keyword-arg)"
                driver.header_overrides = {'Referer': 'https://google.com'}
                driver.set_page_load_timeout(30)
                try:
                    print("Driver Setting up")
                    driver.get(url) #getting the url
                    print("URL lancée")
                except Exception as err:
                    print(err)

                
                
            except:
                driver.quit() # bye bye driver
            
                
```

selenium wire Chrome class : 

```python
class Chrome(InspectRequestsMixin, _Chrome):
    """Extends the Chrome webdriver to provide additional methods for inspecting requests."""

    def __init__(self, *args, seleniumwire_options=None, **kwargs):
        """Initialise a new Chrome WebDriver instance.

        Args:
            seleniumwire_options: The seleniumwire options dictionary.
        """
        if seleniumwire_options is None:
            seleniumwire_options = {}

        self._client = AdminClient()
        addr, port = self._client.create_proxy(
            port=seleniumwire_options.pop('port', 0),
            options=seleniumwire_options
        )

        if 'port' not in seleniumwire_options:  # Auto config mode
            try:
                capabilities = kwargs.pop('desired_capabilities')
            except KeyError:
                capabilities = DesiredCapabilities.CHROME.copy()

            capabilities['proxy'] = {
                'proxyType': 'manual',
                'httpProxy': '{}:{}'.format(addr, port),
                'sslProxy': '{}:{}'.format(addr, port),
                'noProxy': ''
            }
            capabilities['acceptInsecureCerts'] = True

            kwargs['desired_capabilities'] = capabilities

        super().__init__(*args, **kwargs)

    def quit(self):
        self._client.destroy_proxy()
        super().quit()
```

you see we can read  "seleniumwire_options=None" so i don't know were is the problem... 
or its maybe a mistake of my part !



versions i use :
selenium.version :
3.141.0

seleniumwire.version :
2.1.1

chromedriver :
ChromeDriver 84.0.4147.30


pylint --version output :
pylint 2.6.0
astroid 2.4.2
Python 3.7.8 (tags/v3.7.8:4b47a5b6ba, Jun 28 2020, 08:53:46) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)]

If you can help me or just give me a hug (it also helps) please comment.
Thank you.

items.title: Interacting with iframe doesn't work using switch_to.frame with ChromeDriver
items.body:
```
from seleniumwire import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
from webdriver_manager.chrome import ChromeDriverManager
import time

url = 'https://sahkovertailu.fi/'
options = {
    'suppress_connection_errors': False,
    'connection_timeout': None# Show full tracebacks for any connection errors
}
chrome_options = Options()
chrome_options.add_argument("--start-maximized")
chrome_options.add_argument('--auto-open-devtools-for-tabs')
chrome_options.add_argument('--log-level=2')

driver = webdriver.Chrome(ChromeDriverManager().install(), seleniumwire_options=options, chrome_options=chrome_options)

if driver.requests is not None:
    del driver.requests
driver.get(url)

iframe = driver.find_element_by_xpath("//iframe[contains(@src, 'privacy')]")
driver.switch_to.frame(iframe)
button = driver.find_element_by_xpath("//button[contains(., 'OK')]")
button.click()
```
Above code showcases the issue - it should close the cookie consent modal by clicking OK, however this does not work. Using firefox with `from webdriver_manager.firefox import GeckoDriverManager` however works.

requests = driver.requests
Returns all the data needed. Url, parameters but does not return data that is transmitted by the post.

```

In the output, I get all the requested URL instead of scoped URL. I need only the scoped URL to be captured here.

items.title: Selenium-wire proxy blocking requests
items.body:
I've made a small sample code which shows that the proxy server (no proxy!) does not allow Selenium-wire to catch traffic when navigating to a new page.

```
#!C:/Python38-32/python.exe
	
from seleniumwire import webdriver  # Import from seleniumwire
from selenium.webdriver.common.keys import Keys

driver = webdriver.Firefox()

driver.get('https://www.google.se/')

useridInput = driver.find_element_by_name('q')
useridInput.click();
	
useridInput.send_keys('test'); 
driver.find_element_by_name("q").send_keys(Keys.ENTER)

for request in driver.requests:
    if request.response:
        print(
            request.url
        )
```

The first page is loaded correctly but after hitting ENTER, Firefox complains:
**The proxy server is refusing connections
Firefox is configured to use a proxy server that is refusing connections.**

I'm on a simple home network with **no proxy** configured in Firefox. When checking Firefox settings at the end of the script, I noticed the proxy settings are set to **Manual**.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/891874/88026170-c3636e00-cb35-11ea-8a7d-1e3a6d880842.png)

Using Selenium instead of Selenium-wire and removing the **driver.requests** bit fixes the issue but prevents me from catching the XHR responses...

**Edit:**
I've found some similar topics/issues on this page but none of them seems to be the exact same.
I'm using selenium-wire-2.0.0

Here is the code I used,

`urlstring = "https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/the_hateful_eight"
           _driver.get(urlstring)
            _driver.wait_for_request(urlstring, timeout=30)
            # Get status Code for the URL request made
            first_request = self._driver.requests[0]
            if (first_request.response.status_code == 200):
                htmlRet = _driver.page_source # throws exception`

items.title: Key error Content-Length
items.body:
For this code:

```
from seleniumwire import webdriver  # Import from seleniumwire

# Create a new instance of the Firefox driver
driver = webdriver.Firefox()

# Go to the Google home page
driver.get('https://www.mycompany.com/')

# Access requests via the `requests` attribute
for request in driver.requests:
    if request.response:
        print(
            request.path,
            request.response.status_code,
            request.response.headers['Content-Type']
        )
```

It first logs several requests, but then fails followingly:

> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File ".\test.py", line 15, in <module>
>     request.response.headers['Content-Type']
>   File "D:\envs\cbot-GvGARpUM\lib\site-packages\seleniumwire\webdriver\request.py", line 293, in __getitem__
>     return self._store[key.lower()][1]
> KeyError: 'content-type'
> PS D:\main\gdrive\core\cbot\dmxbot>

items.title: Can't use selenium-wire inside AWS lambda
items.body:
Trying to use Selenium-wire inside AWS lambda. But it fails with the following error.

> OSError: [Errno 30] Read-only file system: '/home/sbx_user1051'

Hope selenium-wire try to write some file to disk while calling,
`driver = webdriver.Chrome(executable_path="/var/task/driver/chromedriver",chrome_options=chrome_options)`

Help me with this issue

items.title: [Feature Request] Modify Request: params_overrides & querystring_overrides
wait_for_request() randomly raising TimeoutException after being resolved
items.body:
I'm running a script to automate the checkout on Shopify but `wait_for_request()` seems to randomly raise a `TimeoutException` in the same script during different runs.

`driver.wait_for_request("add.js", timeout=ADD_CART_WAIT)` is what I'm calling to wait for the `add.js` request to complete and is how I know that the item has been added to cart after clicking the "add to cart" button. What's strange is that this exception is raised even after `wait_for_request()` has completed successfully. It waits for `add.js`, sees the response, and the script continues to run, but midway this function raises a `TimeoutException`.

Not sure what is happening here and it's hard to reproduce since it shows up randomly but I can update this post with more info if needed.

items.title: Chromium 80.0.3987.162 unexpectedly loses connection to the internet [Debian 10.4, v1.2.3]
items.body:
When running a script, the browser will sometimes return `ERR_EMPTY_RESPONSE` and upon attempting a reload returns `ERR_PROXY_CONNECTION_FAILED`, most likey due to Selenium closing from a time out.  The annoying thing about this bug is that I have no way of accounting for it and comes up quite randomly, thus making reproducing it quite a hassle. Do keep in mind that I am running Debian via [Crostini](https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromiumos/docs/+/master/containers_and_vms.md), although I run into no issues when browsing the internet normally.

My full script (downloads streams and subtitles from vrv.co; episodeScraper() test link: https://vrv.co/watch/GR8DD279R/Are-You-Afraid-of-the-Dark:The-Tale-of-the-Phantom-Cab , seasonScraper test link: https://vrv.co/series/GRXJ020MY/Are-You-Afraid-of-the-Dark) :
 
``` python
from seleniumwire import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.chrome.options import Options
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait
from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
from wget import download
from re import sub
import os
import requests
from sys import exit


def episodeScraper(username, password, url, path=""):

    driver = webdriver.Chrome(os.path.abspath("chromedriver"))
    wait = WebDriverWait(driver, 120)

    # Login to VRV in order to have the 'streams?' link revealed

    print("Logging in...")
    driver.get(url)
    driver.implicitly_wait(15)

    element = wait.until(
        EC.element_to_be_clickable(
            (
                By.CSS_SELECTOR,
                "#content > div > div.erc-header > div.header-content > div.header-right > ul > li:nth-child(4) > div > div.erc-header-tile",
            )
        )
    )  # Enable account dropdown
    element.click()

    element = wait.until(
        EC.element_to_be_clickable(
            (
                By.XPATH,
                "/html/body/div[1]/div/div[2]/div[1]/div[3]/ul/li[4]/div/div[3]/div/a[2]",
            )
        )
    )  # Click on sign in button
    element.click()

    element = wait.until(
        EC.element_to_be_clickable((By.CLASS_NAME, "email-input"))
    )  # Entering username
    element.send_keys(username)

    element = wait.until(
        EC.element_to_be_clickable((By.CLASS_NAME, "password-input"))
    )  # Entering password
    element.send_keys(password)

    element = wait.until(
        EC.element_to_be_clickable((By.CLASS_NAME, "signin-submit"))
    )  # Submit user info
    element.click()
    driver.implicitly_wait(15)

    # Creating a folder name format and ripping an HD thumbnail via Beautiful Soup

    print("Ripping title name and thumbnail...")

    wait.until(
        EC.presence_of_element_located(
            (
                By.CSS_SELECTOR,
                "#content > div > div.app-body-wrapper > div > div.video-content > div.content > div.media-metadata > a > img",
            )
        )
    )  # Wait for source of title to load
    wait.until(
        EC.presence_of_element_located((By.CLASS_NAME, "video-player"))
    )  # Wait for video player to load

    page_soup = BeautifulSoup(driver.page_source, "html.parser")
    folder_name = os.path.join(
        path,
        page_soup.title.string.split("Watch on VRV")[0]
        + page_soup.find_all("img", class_="c-content-image")[0]["alt"],
    )

    if not os.path.exists(folder_name):
        os.makedirs(folder_name)

    driver.switch_to.frame(
        driver.find_element_by_tag_name("iframe")
    )  # Switch to video player frame
    wait.until(EC.presence_of_element_located((By.CLASS_NAME, "vjs-poster")))
    video_soup = BeautifulSoup(driver.page_source, "html.parser")
    thumbnail_url = sub(
        r"(background-image: url\(\"|\"\);)",
        "",
        video_soup.find("div", class_="vjs-poster")["style"],
        0,
    )
    thumbnail = download(
        thumbnail_url, out=os.path.join(folder_name, "thumbnail.jpeg")
    )
    driver.switch_to.default_content()  # Return to main content
    driver.implicitly_wait(15)

    # Parse the browser requests in order to find the "?streams" link and downloading the playlist and subtitles

    print("Downloading video and subtitles...")

    request = driver.wait_for_request(
        "/cms/v2/US/M3/boomerang,cartoonhangover,crunchyroll,fandor,hidive,mondo,nicksplat,roosterteeth,tested,vrvselect/videos/",
        timeout=120,
    )
    stream_json = requests.get(request.path, headers={"User-Agent": "vrv-dl"}).json()
    driver.quit()

    if stream_json == None:
        exit("Couldln't locate the ?streams link; try, try again.")
    else:
        stream = download(
            stream_json["streams"]["adaptive_dash"][""]["url"],
            out=os.path.join(folder_name, "stream.m3u8"),
        )
        subs = download(
            stream_json["subtitles"]["en-US"]["url"],
            out=os.path.join(folder_name, "subtitles.ass"),
        )

    print(
        "\n==============================\n Stream at: {0} \nSubtitles at: {1} \nThumbnail at {2} \nConvert and embed at your leisure, although you can watch the .m3u8 file locally as long as you have an internet conncection.".format(
            stream, subs, thumbnail
        )
    )


def seasonScraper(username, password, url, path="output"):
    driver = webdriver.Chrome(os.path.abspath("chromedriver"))
    wait = WebDriverWait(driver, 20)

    driver.get(url)
    wait.until(
        EC.presence_of_all_elements_located((By.CLASS_NAME, "card-link"))
    )  # Where the episode links are located
    wait.until(EC.presence_of_element_located((By.CLASS_NAME, 'c-content-image'))) #Where the cover is located

    page_soup = BeautifulSoup(driver.page_source, "html.parser")
    folder_name = os.path.join(
        path, page_soup.find("div", class_="series-title").string
    )
    if not os.path.exists(folder_name):
        os.makedirs(folder_name)
    download(page_soup.select("#content > div > div.app-body-wrapper > div > div.content > div.series-metadata > div.erc-series-poster.series-poster > img")[0]['src'], out=os.path.join(folder_name, "cover.jpeg"))

    episodes = page_soup.find_all("a", class_="card-link")
    episode_links = []
    for item in episodes:
        episode_links.append("https://vrv.co" + item["href"])
    driver.quit()

    for item in episode_links:
        episodeScraper(username, password, item, folder_name)
```

from seleniumwire import webdriver

class Tests(unittest.TestCase):

items.title: Change upstream proxy on fly
items.body:
Hi, Until now, I'm used to use Selenium alone against Gecko driver and through HTTP proxies that I'm changing on fly executing Javascript code from Python. But these days I encounter the new need to be able to handle proxy with basic authentication. So, I listed some possibilities and Selenium Wire appears to be a nice, light and efficient one. It works like a charm passing infos about proxy to webdriver constructor/init, but I don't see any out-of-the-box method to change the proxy on the fly. My previous way was to change it at Firefox level, but as I understand, Selenium Wire introduces its own proxy on 127.0.0.1 and my proxy becomes an upstream one... Thus, chained proxy change has to take place in Selenium Wire only. 
­
**Is it possible to add the possibility to update upstream proxy info in Selenium Wire or did I missed a point since it's already possible?**
­
However, thanks for Selenium Wire; even if no proxy change for now, I think I'll use it just because of the possibility to reach the HTTP status code (big lack in Selenium and BMP appears to be a little heavy for me). Bravo!

--
Windows 7 + Linux CentOS 7
Python 3.7
Selenium 3.141.0
Selenium Wire 1.1.2

items.title: seleniumwire.proxy.handler:code 400, message Bad request syntax
items.body:
Hi,
First of all, thank you so much for developing this library! I tried using Selenium Wire like [mitmproxy's upstream mode](https://docs.mitmproxy.org/stable/concepts-modes/#upstream-proxy) by running the following code. mitmproxy doesn't support socks proxy in the upstream proxy, but Selenium Wire does.
```
from seleniumwire import webdriver
import logging
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

options = {
    'proxy': {
        'http': 'socks5://127.0.0.1:9050',   # This goes to Tor
        'https': 'socks5://127.0.0.1:9050',  # This goes to Tor
	'verify_ssl': False,
	'suppress_connection_errors': False
    }
}

driver = webdriver.Firefox(seleniumwire_options=options)
driver.get("URL")

while True:
	pass
```
So, my purpose was to keep the Selenium Wire's internal proxy running, as if it was running in the standalone mode and chain it with Tor. I know the standalone mode already exists but it is not possible to specify the upstream proxy in the standalone mode. _This might be my little feature request within this issue 😀_

Later, I gathered the port number for Selenium Wire's proxy from the terminal window and I plugged it into [Tor Browser's proxy configuration settings](https://tb-manual.torproject.org/running-tor-browser/). Tor Browser is a modified version of Firefox and it is compatible with Selenium.

During the start-up, the Tor Browser negotiates with various Tor relays to establish a circuit. The negotiations work great over Selenium Wire's proxy until a point, and I keep getting the "Bad request syntax" after that point:
```
DEBUG:seleniumwire.proxy.handler:78.31.64.201:443 200
DEBUG:seleniumwire.proxy.handler:51.77.251.192:443 200
DEBUG:seleniumwire.proxy.handler:95.216.33.58:443 200
DEBUG:seleniumwire.proxy.handler:78.46.104.112:443 200
DEBUG:seleniumwire.proxy.handler:188.24.66.96:443 200
DEBUG:seleniumwire.proxy.handler:code 400, message Bad request syntax ('\x00\x00\x07\x00\x06\x00\x03\x00\x04\x00\x05')
NoneType: None
DEBUG:seleniumwire.proxy.handler:95.216.33.58:443 HTTPStatus.BAD_REQUEST
DEBUG:seleniumwire.proxy.handler:code 400, message Bad request syntax ('\x00\x00\x07\x00\x06\x00\x03\x00\x04\x00\x05')
NoneType: None
DEBUG:seleniumwire.proxy.handler:code 400, message Bad request syntax ('\x00\x00\x07\x00\x06\x00\x03\x00\x04\x00\x05')
NoneType: None
```
Do you have any idea why this happens? What is this error even? What I am doing is probably out of the scope of Selenium Wire library but I still wanted to get your opinion.

items.title: High CPU usage on a request thread
items.body:
Hi. I've been using selenium-wire for some months mostly without problem. 

Some days ago I updated from 1.0.x to the latest version 1.1.1 and I noticed that the entire script I run was noticeably slow and the python process would be using maximum cpu usage (about 6-9% on a 16 thread cpu). 

After some digging I found that a request thread was the problem. To make sure it was a request thread I named them "REQUEST".

> threading.enumerate()
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/65993008/82973749-39b87980-9fa6-11ea-88fc-fd829b799fe9.png)
> Python.exe seen on Process Explorer
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/65993008/82973774-4b9a1c80-9fa6-11ea-9cda-edc0d0d55cab.png)

I had set connection_timeout: None on the options (which I forgot to change for months), but changing it to some number didn't make the request go away after the timeout.

I use chromedriver, set the requests with driver.scopes and all of those requests are XHR/FETCH with JSON responses; checking the network tab on DevTools doesn't show any failed request or weird stuff happening. Since the only thing I changed from the selenium-wire code is the request thread name I don't even know what starts the problem and other than that I have no reproduction steps.

For now, the problem is not present when using version 1.0.10. I might look into it some more if someone has the same problem.

items.title: Selenium-wire closes browser automatically in django project
items.body:
I am working on a very small django project. I am using Selenium-wire in my project because I need to collect the network request. Everything works as expected and when I head over to 127.0.0.1:8000 selenium-wire opens up a new chrome browser to start exploring and collecting the network data. so far so good. unfortunately, after around 30 seconds the window (Chrom browser) that was opened by Seleniumwire gets closed without any error. Can you please help me with this matter?

items.title: Negative scoping of requests capture: exclude certain domains
items.body:
The scoping of request capture is useful because the browser makes a lot of requests in the background that are not relevant for the task at hand. But sometimes a website triggers unexpected requests that I would want to see but that would not be captured by positively scoping as shown in the example: https://github.com/wkeeling/selenium-wire#scoping-request-capture

I have tried to use regex in `driver.scopes` to negatively scope ie exclude domains from the capture list to avoid noise and save memory, using the following regex notation:

```
r'(?i)^((?!(cdn\.mozilla\.net|services\.mozilla\.com)/).)*$'
```

It appears that certain requests from those domains are still showing up.

For example the following request just showed up even though `driver.scopes` is configured with the above regex:

```
'path': 'https://shavar.services.mozilla.com/downloads?client=navclient-auto-ffox&appver=74.0&pver=2.2'
```

This request should have been excluded by the regex, but it still shows up. If I try the regex manually it seems to work fine (ie the path is excluded).

Any ideas on why this is happening?

**UPDATE**
My bad ! I was missing a `^` in my regex (`CaptureRequestHandler` uses `regex.search` but I was testing with `regex.match`)

items.title: Add attribute to request to retrieve the query string
items.body:
In order to retrieve the query string from the request, you have to manually parse the `request.path` - e.g.

query_string = parse.urlsplit(request.path).query
```

We should look at adding a `query_string` attribute to the `request` object to allow more convenient access to the query string.

from selenium.webdriver import DesiredCapabilities

items.body:
Hi!

I was trying to change a pages content using custom_response_handler, but Firefox kept giving me corruptedContentError: 
```2019-11-18 21:03:25,270 DEBUG https://www.zombo.com/ 200
2019-11-18 21:03:25,423 DEBUG http://127.0.0.1:39549 "POST /session/994ca285-44ee-4a20-bbcb-ab0087dd9798/url HTTP/1.1" 500 545
2019-11-18 21:03:25,423 DEBUG Finished Request
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "proj/runner.py", line 29, in <module>
    r.main()
  File "proj/runner.py", line 21, in main
    method(**flowitem['args'])
  File "/home/priit/Repositories/proj/proj/actions.py", line 144, in driver_load_url
    self.browser.get(url)
  File "/home/priit/Repositories/proj/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 333, in get
    self.execute(Command.GET, {'url': url})
  File "/home/priit/Repositories/proj/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 321, in execute
    self.error_handler.check_response(response)
  File "/home/priit/Repositories/proj/venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/errorhandler.py", line 242, in check_response
    raise exception_class(message, screen, stacktrace)
selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: Reached error page: about:neterror?e=corruptedContentErrorv2&u=https%3A//www.zombo.com/&c=UTF-8&f=regular&d=The%20site%20at%20https%3A//www.zombo.com/%20has%20experienced%20a%20network%20protocol%20violation%20that%20cannot%20be%20repaired.
```

After some digging I discovered that changes to content length cause the issue, looks like changed value is appended to headers keeping the old value as well. 
```
---
Server: Apache
Last-Modified: Sat, 21 Sep 2002 03:22:21 GMT
Accept-Ranges: bytes
Content-Length: 1604
Content-Type: text/html

---
Date: Mon, 18 Nov 2019 19:06:21 GMT
Server: Apache
Last-Modified: Sat, 21 Sep 2002 03:22:21 GMT
Accept-Ranges: bytes
Content-Length: 1604
Content-Type: text/html
Content-Length: 2055
```

The headers are stored in a [MessageClass.](https://docs.python.org/3/library/http.server.html#http.server.BaseHTTPRequestHandler.MessageClass
) Which according to [docs](https://docs.python.org/3/library/email.compat32-message.html#email.message.Message) should be cleared using `__delitem__` to make sure only one key is present.

I have fixed this here: https://github.com/pr11t/selenium-wire/commit/f01f7bf04d3733f9ab9b1f26364e0a10a422360e

items.title: [Feature request] Modify request responses
items.body:
It may be out of the use case for this project, but I think it'd be very useful to write `mitmproxy`-style response handlers to inject various things into the webpage before the page load. Here's a simple `mitmproxy`-style response handler that could be useful. It parses text/html requests that respond with the status code 200 and injects some simple js code.

```
    def response(self, flow):
        # only process 200 responses of html content
        if flow.response.headers['Content-Type'] != 'text/html':
            return
        if not flow.response.status_code == 200:
            return

        # inject the script tag
        parsed_html = html.fromstring(flow.response.text)
        container = parsed_html.head or parsed_html.body
        if container:
            script = builder.SCRIPT('alert("injected")', type='text/javascript')
            container.insert(0, script)
            flow.response.text = parsed_html
```

Exclude requests by content type to decrease loading time
items.body:
Thanks for your work on selenium-wire! However, I'm facing some performance issues. Opening a single webpage sometimes takes +60s and thus results in a timeout. A reason seems to be that selenium-wire processes all non-resources (images, fonts). 

My log file contains a lot of "Capturing response" messages. A possible for a speedup would be to exclude all those requests, i.e., to have a filter for unwanted content types. Is this currently possible? Or what would be a starting point to contribute such a feature?

items.title: Possible bug in selenium-wire response.body
items.body:
The problem is that sometimes response.body type is list or dict when expected type is either bytes or None. Usually this occurs when response body is JSON-formatted text. I don’t think this is intended feature and bytes in this situation would be easier to handle. 

Here is a minimal example program that reproduces the issue and outputs lines that contains `type(request.response.body)`, `request.path` and `request.response.body`. I chose radiopaedia.org as example, but this seems to be issue anywhere where JSON-objects are used for example https://www.nytimes.com. 

It seems that JSON-object formatted responses are converted to dict and JSON-array formatted are converted to list. 

Few examples from output:
```
<class 'bytes'>   https://radiopaedia.org/cases/colles-fracture-10   b'<!DOCTYPE html>\n\n<html lang="en-GB">\n<head>\n … 
<class 'list'>   https://radiopaedia.org/studies/44157/stacks?lang=gb   [{'modality': 'X-ray', 'images': [{'id’: …
<class 'dict'>   https://radiopaedia.org/api/v1/countries/current   {'id': 72, 'code': 'FI', 'name': 'Finland', 'newsletter_auto_opt_in': False}
```

Notice that these print-outputs are from list and dict objects, not from original response bodies. Actual responses are JSON-formatted strings with double quotes instead of single quotes. 

Here is an actual response of https://radiopaedia.org/api/v1/countries/current that I got from Google Chrome DevTools Network:
```
"{"id":72,"code":"FI","name":"Finland","newsletter_auto_opt_in":false}”
```

items.title: driver.header_overrides doesn't set all headers
items.body:
Test script:

```
import logging
from pprint import pprint
from seleniumwire import webdriver 

logging.basicConfig(format='%(levelname)s:%(message)s', level=logging.DEBUG)

chrome_options = webdriver.ChromeOptions()
chrome_options.add_argument("--no-sandbox")
chrome_options.add_argument("--headless")
chrome_options.add_argument("--disable-gpu")

driver = webdriver.Chrome(
    chrome_options=chrome_options,
    executable_path="/usr/lib/chromium-browser/chromedriver",
)

driver._client.set_header_overrides(
    headers={
        "User-Agent": "Mozilla/5.0 (test)",
        "Accept": "text/html, foo/bar",
        "Accept-Language": "en,de;q=0.7,fr;q=0.3",
        'New-Header1': 'Some Value',
    })

driver.get("https://www.google.com")

for request in driver.requests:
    if request.response:
        print(request.path, request.response.status_code)
        pprint(dict(request.headers))
```

output from first request:
```
https://www.google.com/ 200
{'Accept': 'text/html, foo/bar',
 'Accept-Encoding': 'gzip, deflate',
 'Connection': 'keep-alive',
 'Host': 'www.google.com',
 'Upgrade-Insecure-Requests': '1',

So: "Accept" and "User-Agent" are set, but not "Accept-Language" and "New-Header1" ...

Maybe related to chrome usage ?!?

items.title: Certificates not valid on Chrome when running standalone proxy
items.body:
This does not affect selenium tests and is only an issue when running Selenium Wire in standalone mode with:

`python -m seleniumwire standaloneproxy port=12345`

When using Chrome with the standalone proxy it reports that the server's certificate is not valid. This is because the certificate is created without a Subject Alternative Name. This is not a problem on older versions of Chrome, but is on newer versions as Chrome has tightened up its security.

The solution is to ensure that OpenSSL sets the Subject Alternative Name when generating certificates. There is a command line option for this in newer versions of OpenSSL but not in older versions.

items.title: Gzipped content slow to load
items.body: In some cases, pages that use a Content-Encoding of gzip seem to be slower to load when using Selenium Wire. This doesn't seem to affect all gzipped pages but has been noticed on pages being served by nginx using it's gzip module.
